examples.Rmd

WARNING: This article is incomplete and still very much a work in progress!

This article aims to show a wide variety of examples in which we use Large Language Models (LLMs) to help explain the output from various statistical tests and models.

Explaining the output from a two-sample t-test

The following example is taken from a tutorial on paired t-tests. Here we use an independent two-sample t-test to (inappropriately) analyze paired data.

library(statlingua)

# Define additional context to pass to `explain()`; this should include 
# any additional background information about the data and research question.
context <- "
An instructor wants to use two exams in her classes next year. This year, she gives both exams to the students. She wants to know if the exams are equally difficult and wants to check this by comparing the two sets of scores. Here is the data:

 student exam_1_score exam_2_score
     Bob           63           69
    Nina           65           65
     Tim           56           62
    Kate          100           91
  Alonzo           88           78
    Jose           83           87
  Nikhil           77           79
   Julia           92           88
   Tohru           90           85
 Michael           84           92
    Jean           68           69
   Indra           74           81
   Susan           87           84
   Allen           64           75
    Paul           71           84
  Edwina           88           82
"

# Create the data set
exam_scores <- tibble::tribble(
  ~student,  ~exam_1_score, ~exam_2_score,
  "Bob",     63,            69,
  "Nina",    65,            65,
  "Tim",     56,            62,
  "Kate",    100,           91,
  "Alonzo",  88,            78,
  "Jose",    83,            87,
  "Nikhil",  77,            79,
  "Julia",   92,            88,
  "Tohru",   90,            85,
  "Michael", 84,            92,
  "Jean",    68,            69,
  "Indra",   74,            81,
  "Susan",   87,            84,
  "Allen",   64,            75,
  "Paul",    71,            84,
  "Edwina",  88,            82
)

# Run a two-sample t-test
(tt <- t.test(exam_scores$exam_1_score, y = exam_scores$exam_2_score))
Welch Two Sample t-test

data: exam_scoresexam1scoreandexamscoresexam_1_score and exam_scoresexam_2_score t = -0.33602, df = 27.307, p-value = 0.7394 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -9.322782 6.697782 sample estimates: mean of x mean of y 78.1250 79.4375


# Inititalize client
client <- ellmer::chat_google_gemini(echo = "none")
#> Using model = "gemini-2.0-flash".
ex <- explain(tt, client = client, context = context)
cat(ex)

Here’s an explanation of the Welch Two Sample t-test output, given the context you’ve provided.

1. Summary of the Statistical Test

  • Name of the test: Welch Two Sample t-test (also known as an Independent Samples t-test with unequal variances).
  • Purpose: This test is used to compare the means of two independent groups. In this case, the instructor is using it to compare the average score on exam 1 to the average score on exam 2. The goal is to determine if there’s a statistically significant difference in the mean scores of the two exams.
  • Key Assumptions:
    • The two samples (exam scores from exam 1 and exam 2) are independent.
    • The data in each group is approximately normally distributed.
    • The variances of the two groups are not assumed to be equal (that’s the key difference between Welch’s t-test and the Student’s t-test).

2. Appropriateness of the Statistical Test

Given the instructor’s research question and the data available, the Welch Two Sample t-test appears to be a reasonable choice. The instructor wants to compare the difficulty of two exams by comparing the scores, and the t-test is designed for comparing means. The Welch’s version is used because we don’t know if the variance in exam scores is the same between the two exams. This test could be inappropriate if the assumptions are not met.

3. Suggestions for Checking Assumptions of the Statistical Test

Before drawing firm conclusions, it’s crucial to check the assumptions of the t-test. Here’s how:

  • Independence: This assumption relies on the study design. Since each student took both exams, and we are treating each set of exam scores as separate samples, this assumption might not be met. A paired t-test might be more appropriate here, as scores from the same student on different exams will not be independent.
  • Normality: We need to check if the exam score distributions are approximately normal.
    • Histograms: Create histograms of exam_1_score and exam_2_score separately. Look for bell-shaped distributions that are roughly symmetrical. Large deviations from normality (skewness, multiple peaks) would be a concern.
    • Q-Q Plots: Create quantile-quantile plots (Q-Q plots) for both sets of exam scores. If the data are normally distributed, the points on the Q-Q plot should fall approximately along a straight line. Deviations from the line indicate departures from normality. Use the function qqnorm() in R to check for normality graphically.
    • Shapiro-Wilk Test: You can use the Shapiro-Wilk test (shapiro.test() in R) to formally test for normality. However, be cautious when interpreting the results, especially with small sample sizes, as the test can be overly sensitive. Focus on the graphical methods first.
  • Equality of Variances: Although Welch’s t-test doesn’t assume equal variances, it’s still good to get a sense of whether the variances are drastically different, as very unequal variances can sometimes affect the test’s performance, especially with unequal sample sizes (which you don’t have here, but it’s good to keep in mind).
    • Side-by-side boxplots: Compare the spread (IQR, or interquartile range) of the two boxplots. If one boxplot is much wider than the other, it indicates a larger variance.
    • Levene’s test: The leveneTest() in the car package in R provides a formal test for the equality of variances.

4. Interpretation of the Output

Let’s break down the output:

  • t = -0.33602: This is the calculated t-statistic. It represents the difference between the sample means relative to the variability within the samples. The further this value is from 0, the stronger the evidence against the null hypothesis.
  • df = 27.307: This is the degrees of freedom. Because Welch’s t-test does not assume equal variances, the degrees of freedom are calculated in a more complex way than in the Student’s t-test. The degrees of freedom are used to determine the p-value.
  • p-value = 0.7394: This is the probability of observing a t-statistic as extreme as, or more extreme than, -0.33602 if there is truly no difference in the mean exam scores (i.e., if the null hypothesis is true). In other words, even if the two exams were equally difficult, there’s a 73.94% chance you’d see a difference in sample means as big as (or bigger than) the one observed in this sample.
  • alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0: This states the alternative hypothesis being tested: that the population means of the two exam scores are different. This is a two-sided test, meaning it’s looking for differences in either direction (exam 1 harder or exam 2 harder).
  • 95 percent confidence interval: -9.322782 6.697782: This provides a range of plausible values for the true difference in the population means (mean of exam 1 minus mean of exam 2). We are 95% confident that the true difference in means lies between -9.32 and 6.70. Because this interval includes 0, it suggests that a difference of zero (i.e., no difference in means) is a plausible value. The units here are exam score points.
  • sample estimates:
    • mean of x = 78.1250: This is the sample mean of exam 1 scores.
    • mean of y = 79.4375: This is the sample mean of exam 2 scores.

5. Overall Conclusion

Using a significance level of α=0.05\alpha = 0.05, since the p-value (0.7394) is greater than α\alpha, we fail to reject the null hypothesis. There is insufficient evidence to conclude that there is a statistically significant difference in the mean scores of the two exams. Based on this analysis, the instructor does not have enough evidence to say that one exam is significantly harder than the other.

6. Caution

This explanation was generated by a Large Language Model. Critically review the output and consult additional statistical resources or experts to ensure correctness and a full understanding. Remember to check the assumptions of the test to ensure the validity of the conclusions. Furthermore, given that the scores for each student were obtained on both tests, the assumption of independence may not hold. A paired t-test may be more appropriate.
